parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several actions are available to encourage natural foraging behaviors in captive primates.
[Statement 2]: Scattering food throughout an enclosure increases feeding and exploratory behaviors in rhesus macaques.
[Statement 3]: Scattering food throughout an enclosure reduces abnormal behaviors in chimpanzees.
[Statement 4]: Scattering food throughout an enclosure reduces aggression in lemurs.
[Statement 5]: Scattering food throughout an enclosure increases foraging and activity levels in gorillas.
[Statement 6]: Hiding food in containers such as boxes, baskets or tubes increases activity levels and foraging behaviors in lemurs and gibbons.
[Statement 7]: Presenting food in puzzle feeders increases foraging behavior and tool use.
[Statement 8]: Presenting food in puzzle feeders may also increase aggression.
[Statement 9]: Presenting food in puzzle feeders increases time spent feeding while reducing inactivity.
[Statement 10]: Presenting food items whole instead of processed increases the amount consumed in macaques.
[Statement 11]: Presenting food items whole instead of processed increases the time spent feeding in macaques.
[Statement 12]: Providing cut branches allows captive gorillas to use the same processing skills as wild gorillas when foraging, particularly when presented with stinging nettles.
[Statement 13]: Providing live invertebrates reduces inactivity in captive loris to levels seen in wild loris.
[Statement 14]: Providing live invertebrates increases foraging in captive loris to levels seen in wild loris.
[Statement 15]: Enrichment tasks are completed faster when monkeys are in groups compared to feeding alone.
[Statement 16]: Groupmates encourage eating unfamiliar foods.
[Statement 17]: Smaller crowds increase foraging and object use in chimpanzees.
[Statement 18]: Formulating diets to reflect the nutritional composition of wild foods, including the removal of domestic fruits, can reduce regurgitation and reingestion in gorillas.
[Statement 19]: Formulating diets to reflect the nutritional composition of wild foods can lower aggression and self-directed behavior in lemurs.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What actions are available to encourage natural foraging behaviours in captive primates?
_claude-sonnet-4__What are the potential benefits and negative impacts of using complex feeding devices, like puzzle feeders or prey simulators, for captive primates and carnivores?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Complex feeding devices show both benefits and negative impacts for captive primates and carnivores.
[Statement 2]: For primates, puzzle feeders decreased food sharing.
[Statement 3]: For primates, puzzle feeders increased foraging behaviour and tool use.
[Statement 4]: Puzzle feeders also increased aggression in primates.
[Statement 5]: Puzzle feeders increased the time primates spent feeding.
[Statement 6]: Puzzle feeders reduced inactive time in primates.
[Statement 7]: For carnivores, prey simulation devices including sounds, lures, pulleys and bungees increased activity levels in felids.
[Statement 8]: Prey simulation devices including sounds, lures, pulleys and bungees increased behavioural diversity in felids.
[Statement 9]: Prey simulation devices decreased pacing behaviour in cougars.
[Statement 10]: Prey simulation devices increased walking in cougars.
[Statement 11]: Pacing initially increased in tigers when the tigers were provided with a carcass on a bungee.
[Statement 12]: Live invertebrate prey provided in feeding devices increased explorative behaviours in fennec foxes compared to other types of enrichment.
[Statement 13]: Hiding food around enclosures increased exploring and foraging behaviours in various carnivore species, including black bears, leopard cats, bush dogs, maned wolves and Malayan sun bears.
[Statement 14]: Hiding food around enclosures decreased stereotypical pacing behaviours in various carnivore species.
[Statement 15]: No evidence was found specifically for the use of automated feeders in carnivores.

[Statement 1]: When chimpanzees were fed on unpredictable schedules, inactivity decreased.
[Statement 2]: When the number of feeds per day for chimpanzees was increased, the amount of time the chimpanzees spent feeding increased.
[Statement 3]: When the number of feeds per day for baboons was increased, hair eating also increased.
[Statement 4]: For captive carnivores, multiple studies have documented the effects of unpredictable feeding schedules.
[Statement 5]: An unpredictable feeding schedule reduced the frequency of stereotypic pacing behaviours in tigers and cheetahs.
[Statement 6]: An unpredictable feeding schedule increased territorial behaviour in coyotes.
[Statement 7]: An unpredictable feeding schedule did not affect travelling or foraging in coyotes.
[Statement 8]: An unpredictable feeding schedule increased behavioural diversity in red foxes.
[Statement 9]: An unpredictable feeding schedule increased alertness in a black-footed cat.
[Statement 10]: Large felids fed once every three days paced more frequently on non-feeding days.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__In a zoo environment, what are the documented effects of altering the timing and predictability of feeding schedules for captive primates and carnivores?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Alternatives to processed or commercial pellet diets for captive primates include providing fresh produce.
[Statement 2]: Providing fresh produce to rhesus macaques resulted in the macaques spending more time feeding and less time being inactive.
[Statement 3]: Presenting food items whole instead of processed increased the amount of food consumed by macaques.
[Statement 4]: Presenting food items whole instead of processed increased the time macaques spent feeding.
[Statement 5]: Providing cut branches, such as stinging nettles, allowed captive gorillas to use the same processing skills as wild gorillas to forage.
[Statement 6]: For captive carnivores, feeding whole carcasses is an alternative diet.
[Statement 7]: Feeding whole carcasses reduced pacing levels in lions, leopards, snow leopards and cougars.
[Statement 8]: Feeding whole carcasses increased pacing in tigers.
[Statement 9]: When fed whole rabbit, cheetahs had lower blood protein urea, zinc and vitamin A levels compared to cheetahs fed supplemented beef.
[Statement 10]: Cheetahs fed whole rabbit showed lower levels of inflammatory bowel indicators compared to cheetahs fed supplemented beef.
[Statement 11]: Feeding whole 1 to 3 day old chickens to ocelots resulted in lower digestible energy and fat compared to a commercial diet.
[Statement 12]: In maned wolves, plant-derived protein diets increased digestible energy and dry matter digestibility compared to animal-based protein diets.
[Statement 13]: In maned wolves, plant-derived protein diets decreased mineral retention and plasma taurine levels compared to animal-based protein diets.
[Statement 14]: Providing a fishing cat with live fish increased the cat's hunting behaviour.
[Statement 15]: Providing a fishing cat with live fish decreased the cat's sleeping.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the alternatives to feeding processed or commercial pellet diets to captive primates and carnivores?
_claude-sonnet-4__What dietary modifications are available to better reflect the natural feeding ecology of captive primates?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several dietary modifications are available to better reflect the natural feeding ecology of captive primates.
[Statement 2]: The nutritional composition of diets for captive primates can be modified to reflect the nutritional composition of wild foods.
[Statement 3]: Removing domestic fruits from diets was found to decrease regurgitation and reingestion in gorillas.
[Statement 4]: Feeding lemurs a fruit-free diet was found to reduce aggression and self-directed behavior.
[Statement 5]: Food presentation methods for captive primates can be enhanced by providing cut branches for browse.
[Statement 6]: Captive gorillas used the same processing skills as wild gorillas when presented with stinging nettles.
[Statement 7]: Presenting food items whole instead of processed increased consumption and feeding time in macaques.
[Statement 8]: Foraging opportunities for captive primates can be improved by scattering food throughout enclosures.
[Statement 9]: Scattering food throughout enclosures increased feeding and exploratory behaviors in rhesus macaques.
[Statement 10]: Scattering food throughout enclosures reduced abnormal behaviors in chimpanzees and aggression in lemurs.
[Statement 11]: Scattering food throughout enclosures increased foraging and activity levels in gorillas.
[Statement 12]: Food can be hidden in containers such as boxes and bags for captive primates.
[Statement 13]: Hiding food in containers such as boxes and bags increased activity levels and foraging behaviors in lemurs and gibbons.
[Statement 14]: Presenting food in puzzle feeders decreased food sharing, and increased foraging behavior and tool use, but also increased aggression in some cases.
[Statement 15]: Live vegetation can be provided in planters for foraging.
[Statement 16]: Chimpanzees spent more time foraging when provided with planted rye grass and scattered sunflower seeds.
[Statement 17]: Spatial food distribution can be maximized by utilizing both horizontal and vertical food presentation locations.
[Statement 18]: Monkeys spent longer feeding in bowls positioned at the top of enclosures than on the floor.
[Statement 19]: Feeding schedules for captive primates can be adjusted by changing the number of feeds per day.
[Statement 20]: Changing the number of feeds per day increased feeding time in chimpanzees but also increased hair eating in baboons.

[Statement 1]: Several non-hormonal alternatives are used in captive breeding programs to simulate breeding seasons and encourage amphibian reproduction.
[Statement 2]: Temperature manipulation involves varying enclosure temperature to simulate seasonal changes for amphibians.
[Statement 3]: One study found that a drop in temperature from 20-24°C to 17°C resulted in breeding in one of six female amphibians.
[Statement 4]: Artificial rainfall variation to simulate wet and dry seasons has been shown to stimulate breeding and egg deposition in amphibians.
[Statement 5]: Environmental enrichment approaches for amphibians include providing particular enclosure furniture for calling sites, breeding areas, or egg laying sites.
[Statement 6]: Studies have shown that adding rotting logs and hollow bamboo pipes to amphibian enclosures promoted egg laying.
[Statement 7]: Providing multiple egg laying sites within amphibian enclosures has been shown to promote egg laying.
[Statement 8]: The provision of natural substrate has been successful for amphibian species that do not breed in water, such as burrowing species.
[Statement 9]: Studies show that adding various substrates to enclosures promoted egg laying in certain amphibians.
[Statement 10]: Separating male and female amphibians during non-breeding periods increased clutch size when combined with other breeding stimulation methods.
[Statement 11]: One method to encourage amphibian reproduction is varying enclosure humidity using humidifiers, foggers, or artificial rain.
[Statement 12]: Varying lighting duration and quality to simulate seasonal changes is a method used to encourage amphibian reproduction.
[Statement 13]: Allowing hibernation for temperate amphibian species is a method used to encourage reproduction.
[Statement 14]: Providing dormancy periods for amphibian species from seasonal environments can be used to encourage reproduction.
[Statement 15]: Varying food provision to reflect seasonal availability is a method to encourage amphibian reproduction.
[Statement 16]: Varying water flow is a method used for torrent breeding amphibian species to encourage reproduction.
[Statement 17]: Many methods for encouraging amphibian reproduction, such as varying humidity, light, or food, lack documented evidence of effectiveness.
[Statement 18]: General captive breeding studies indicate that amphibian reproductive success depends on temperature and simulated wet/dry seasons.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__Within captive breeding programs for amphibians, what are the non-hormonal alternatives for simulating a breeding season to encourage reproduction?
_claude-sonnet-4__To reduce aggression among primates housed in social groups, what are the most effective feeding-related interventions?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several feeding-related interventions show effectiveness in reducing aggression among primates in social groups.
[Statement 2]: Scattering food throughout an enclosure was found to reduce aggression in lemurs.
[Statement 3]: Scattering food throughout an enclosure was found to increase feeding and exploratory behaviors in rhesus macaques.
[Statement 4]: Scattering food throughout an enclosure was found to reduce abnormal behaviors in chimpanzees.
[Statement 5]: Dietary composition modifications show promising results for primate behavior.
[Statement 6]: When lemurs were fed a fruit-free diet, aggression and self-directed behavior were lower.
[Statement 7]: Puzzle feeders can increase foraging behavior and tool use in primates.
[Statement 8]: Puzzle feeders can also increase aggression in primates.
[Statement 9]: Feeding schedules are an important factor in primate behavior.
[Statement 10]: Unpredictable feeding schedules can decrease inactivity in chimpanzees.
[Statement 11]: Monkeys complete enrichment tasks more quickly when in social groups compared to when feeding alone.
[Statement 12]: Monkeys eat more unfamiliar foods in the presence of groupmates.
[Statement 13]: Presenting feeds at different crowd levels can increase foraging and object use when smaller crowds are present.
[Statement 14]: The spatial distribution of food is an important factor for primate feeding.
[Statement 15]: Maximizing both horizontal and vertical food presentation locations affects feeding patterns.

[Statement 1]: Several dietary changes can encourage naturalistic behaviors in captive lemurs and macaques.
[Statement 2]: Scattering food throughout an enclosure increased feeding and exploratory behaviors in rhesus macaques.
[Statement 3]: Scattering food throughout an enclosure reduced abnormal behaviors and aggression in lemurs.
[Statement 4]: Formulating diets for lemurs to reflect the nutritional composition of wild foods, including the removal of domestic fruits, led to lower aggression and self-directed behavior.
[Statement 5]: Presenting food items whole instead of processed increased the amount of food consumed by macaques.
[Statement 6]: Presenting food items whole instead of processed increased the time macaques spent feeding.
[Statement 7]: Providing fresh produce instead of pellet feed resulted in rhesus macaques spending more time feeding.
[Statement 8]: Providing fresh produce instead of pellet feed resulted in rhesus macaques spending less time inactive.
[Statement 9]: Using puzzle feeders increased foraging behavior in captive primates.
[Statement 10]: Using puzzle feeders increased the time captive primates spent feeding.
[Statement 11]: Using puzzle feeders decreased the time captive primates were inactive.
[Statement 12]: Providing cut branches for browse allowed primates to use natural processing skills for foraging.
[Statement 13]: Live vegetation in planters increased foraging time in primates.
[Statement 14]: Feeding primates in social groups enhanced food exploration.
[Statement 15]: Feeding primates in social groups enhanced the acceptance of unfamiliar foods.
[Statement 16]: Changing feeding times to unpredictable schedules decreased inactivity in captive primates.
[Statement 17]: Increasing the number of feeds per day increased the time captive primates spent feeding.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__For captive lemurs and macaques, what are the most beneficial dietary changes to encourage naturalistic behaviours?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Social feeding strategies for captive primates show some documented effects.
[Statement 2]: Research on social feeding strategies for captive primates is limited.
[Statement 3]: An enrichment task took less time for monkeys to complete when the monkeys were in social groups than when feeding alone.
[Statement 4]: In the presence of their groupmates, monkeys ate more unfamiliar foods during the first encounter.
[Statement 5]: No evidence was captured for the effects of the strategy of feeding individuals separately.
[Statement 6]: Foraging and object use in chimpanzees increased when smaller crowds were present.
[Statement 7]: When chimpanzees were fed on unpredictable schedules, inactivity decreased.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the trade-offs associated with different social feeding strategies for captive primates?
_claude-sonnet-4__What dietary management strategies are available for captive primates to reduce aggression and abnormal behaviours?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several dietary management strategies have been documented for reducing aggression and abnormal behaviors in captive primates.
[Statement 2]: Formulating diets to reflect the nutritional composition of wild foods, including the removal of domestic fruits, has shown effectiveness.
[Statement 3]: Feeding lemurs a fruit-free diet resulted in lower aggression and self-directed behavior.
[Statement 4]: Food presentation methods significantly impact the behavior of captive primates.
[Statement 5]: Scattering food throughout enclosures has been shown to reduce abnormal behaviors in chimpanzees.
[Statement 6]: Scattering food throughout enclosures has been shown to reduce aggression in lemurs.
[Statement 7]: Scattering food throughout enclosures increased feeding and exploratory behaviors in rhesus macaques.
[Statement 8]: Scattering food throughout enclosures increased foraging activity in gorillas.
[Statement 9]: Puzzle feeders can be beneficial by decreasing food sharing and increasing foraging behavior and tool use.
[Statement 10]: Puzzle feeders may also increase aggression in some cases.
[Statement 11]: Modifications to feeding schedules also influence primate behavior.
[Statement 12]: Unpredictable feeding schedules decreased inactivity in chimpanzees.
[Statement 13]: Increasing the number of feeds per day increased feeding time in chimpanzees.
[Statement 14]: Increasing the number of feeds per day also increased hair eating in baboons.
[Statement 15]: Social feeding arrangements can affect food acceptance.
[Statement 16]: Monkeys eat more unfamiliar foods when in the presence of groupmates.
[Statement 17]: Environmental crowd levels during feeding also affect primate behavior.
[Statement 18]: Smaller crowds during feeding increased foraging and object use in chimpanzees.
[Statement 19]: Providing natural browse such as cut branches allows captive gorillas to use the same processing skills as wild gorillas when foraging.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__In a zoo setting, what are the potential benefits and harms of creating unpredictable feeding schedules for primates and carnivores?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Unpredictable feeding schedules show several benefits for carnivores in zoo settings.
[Statement 2]: For carnivores, unpredictable feeding schedules reduced the frequency of stereotypic pacing behaviors in tigers and cheetahs.
[Statement 3]: Unpredictable feeding schedules increased behavioral diversity in red foxes.
[Statement 4]: Unpredictable feeding schedules increased alertness in black-footed cats.
[Statement 5]: Unpredictable feeding schedules increased territorial behavior in coyotes.
[Statement 6]: The increased territorial behavior in coyotes did not affect the coyotes' traveling or foraging behaviors.
[Statement 7]: Large felids fed once every three days paced more frequently on non-feeding days.
[Statement 8]: Extended periods without food may increase stress-related behaviors in large felids.
[Statement 9]: No direct evidence was found regarding unpredictable feeding schedules for primates.
[Statement 10]: When smaller crowds were present, foraging and object use in chimpanzees increased.
[Statement 11]: Monkeys in social groups completed enrichment tasks more quickly.
[Statement 12]: Monkeys in social groups ate more unfamiliar foods during first encounters.
[Statement 13]: No evidence was captured for the effects on carnivores of altering feeding schedules according to visitor activity.
[Statement 14]: No evidence was captured for the effects on carnivores of providing food during visitor experiences.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__For captive felids in zoos, which food-based enrichment strategies are most effective for increasing activity levels and reducing pacing?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several food-based enrichment strategies have proven effective for captive felids in reducing pacing and increasing activity levels.
[Statement 2]: Hiding food around enclosures has been shown to increase exploring and foraging behaviors in leopard cats.
[Statement 3]: Hiding food around enclosures has been shown to reduce stereotypical pacing in leopard cats.
[Statement 4]: Hiding food around enclosures has been shown to reduce daytime sleeping in Canadian lynx.
[Statement 5]: Providing food on a random temporal schedule significantly reduced the frequency of stereotypic pacing behaviors in tigers and cheetahs.
[Statement 6]: Providing food on a random temporal schedule increased behavioral diversity in red foxes.
[Statement 7]: Providing food on a random temporal schedule increased alertness in black-footed cats.
[Statement 8]: Allocating fast days, which involves feeding once every three days, increased pacing frequency in large felids on non-feeding days.
[Statement 9]: Providing devices to simulate live prey, including lures and pulley systems, increased activity levels and behavioral diversity in felids.
[Statement 10]: Providing carcasses on bungees decreased pacing behavior in cougars.
[Statement 11]: Providing carcasses on bungees increased walking in cougars.
[Statement 12]: Providing carcasses on bungees initially increased pacing in tigers.
[Statement 13]: Presenting food frozen in ice decreased abnormal or stereotypic behaviors in felids.
[Statement 14]: Presenting food frozen in ice increased activity levels in felids.
[Statement 15]: Presenting food frozen in ice increased manipulation behaviors in lions.
[Statement 16]: Providing bones, hides or partial carcasses decreased stereotypic behaviors in lions and tigers.
[Statement 17]: Providing bones, hides or partial carcasses increased activity and manipulation time in felids.
[Statement 18]: Scattering food around enclosures increased locomotion in maned wolves.
[Statement 19]: Scattering food around enclosures influenced spatial usage patterns in maned wolves.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__For captive lemurs and macaques in a zoo setting, what methods of food presentation can increase foraging behaviours?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several food presentation methods have been shown to increase foraging behaviors in captive lemurs and macaques in zoo settings.
[Statement 2]: Scattering food throughout the enclosure increased feeding and exploratory behaviors in rhesus macaques.
[Statement 3]: Scattering food throughout the enclosure increased foraging behavior with higher activity levels in rhesus macaques.
[Statement 4]: For lemurs specifically, scattering food reduced aggression.
[Statement 5]: Hiding food in containers including boxes and bags increased activity levels in lemurs.
[Statement 6]: Hiding food in containers including boxes and bags increased foraging behaviors in lemurs.
[Statement 7]: Presenting whole foods instead of processed or chopped foods increased the amount of food consumed by macaques.
[Statement 8]: Presenting whole foods instead of processed or chopped foods increased the time macaques spent feeding.
[Statement 9]: The use of puzzle feeders increased foraging behavior and time spent feeding.
[Statement 10]: The use of puzzle feeders reduced inactive time.
[Statement 11]: The use of puzzle feeders also increased aggression.
[Statement 12]: Enrichment tasks were completed more efficiently when monkeys were in social groups compared to when monkeys were feeding alone.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the known benefits and harms of using feeding devices that simulate prey or require manipulation for captive carnivores?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Feeding devices that simulate prey or require manipulation for captive carnivores show several documented benefits.
[Statement 2]: The provision of live prey increased explorative behaviours in fennec foxes compared to other types of enrichment.
[Statement 3]: Devices to simulate live prey using lures or pulley systems increased activity levels and behavioural diversity in felids.
[Statement 4]: When cougars were provided with a carcass on a bungee, their pacing behaviour decreased and walking increased.
[Statement 5]: Food frozen in ice decreased abnormal or stereotypic behaviours in bears and felids.
[Statement 6]: Food frozen in ice increased activity levels in bears and felids.
[Statement 7]: Food frozen in ice increased manipulation behaviours in lions.
[Statement 8]: Scattered feeding increased locomotion in maned wolves.
[Statement 9]: Some potential harms were documented regarding feeding devices that simulate prey or require manipulation.
[Statement 10]: When tigers were provided with a carcass on a bungee, their pacing initially increased.
[Statement 11]: Food frozen in ice decreased manipulation behaviours in grizzly bears.
[Statement 12]: While not specific to carnivores, puzzle feeders in primates increased aggression.
[Statement 13]: Puzzle feeders in primates had beneficial effects like increased foraging behaviour and tool use.

[Statement 1]: Alternative husbandry actions for promoting amphibian breeding success in captive settings include environmental manipulation techniques.
[Statement 2]: Temperature variation to simulate seasonal changes can stimulate amphibian breeding.
[Statement 3]: A temperature drop from 20-24°C to 17°C alongside filling an egg laying pond has led to amphibian breeding success.
[Statement 4]: Simulating wet and dry seasons through artificial rainfall has been shown to stimulate breeding and egg deposition.
[Statement 5]: Physical enclosure modifications are critical for amphibian breeding.
[Statement 6]: Providing particular enclosure furniture for calling sites, breeding areas or egg laying sites is a critical modification.
[Statement 7]: Studies show that adding rotting logs, hollow bamboo pipes, and a variety of substrates promoted egg laying.
[Statement 8]: Providing multiple egg laying sites within enclosures has proven effective.
[Statement 9]: Frogs have been found to breed only after being moved to enclosures with various organic substrates and temporary flooding capabilities.
[Statement 10]: Providing natural substrate for non-aquatic breeding species, such as burrowing or tunnel breeders, promoted egg laying when combined with temporary flooding and other interventions.
[Statement 11]: Specialized water features such as artificial aquifers for species that breed in upwelling springs have enabled salamander breeding in captivity.
[Statement 12]: Social and reproductive management includes manipulating sex ratios within enclosures.
[Statement 13]: Manipulating sex ratios within enclosures, when combined with other interventions, has led to successful breeding.
[Statement 14]: Allowing female mate choice increased clutch size when combined with other management practices.
[Statement 15]: Hormone treatments can induce sperm and egg release in amphibians.
[Statement 16]: Studies show that 30-71% of female amphibians treated with hormones produced viable eggs.
[Statement 17]: The success of hormone treatments varies by hormone type, amount and dosing frequency.
[Statement 18]: Breeding similar species first to refine husbandry techniques before working with target species has proven successful for establishing effective protocols for critically endangered species.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__Beyond dietary changes, what alternative husbandry actions can be taken in a captive setting to promote amphibian breeding success?
